/* Coronavirus pandemic */ Restore longstanding wording about Trump's slow response. This was extensively discussed on talk and the removal of "Trump was slow" is against clear consensus there. See  [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Donald_Trump/Archive_115#Reducing_editorialising_and_sensational_language] and related archive threads.
trim
coronavirus task force

In early May, President Trump proposed that the coronavirus task force should be phased out, to accommodate another group centered on reopening the economy. Amid a backlash, Trump publicly stated that the coronavirus task force would continue on "indefinitely". By the end of May, the coronavirus task force was conducting only weekly meetings, instead of the previous daily meetings.

In February 2020, Trump campaign adviser Roger Stone was sentenced to over three years in jail, after being convicted of lying to Congress and witness tampering regarding his attempts to learn more about hacked Democratic emails during the 2016 election. The sentencing judge stated that Stone "was prosecuted for covering up for the president". With Stone yet to report to jail, Trump publicly stated that Stone "can sleep well at night".

On January 8, Iran retaliated by launching airstrikes on [[Al Asad Air Base]] in Iraq; initially the Trump administration claimed no Americans suffered injuries, then Trump said injuries were not "very serious", but by February 2020, over 100 [[traumatic brain injuries]] were diagnosed in U.S. troops

trim extra refs. .... Trump posed for photographs in front of the church, holding a Bible aloft, and then had his officials join him for more photos, before walking back to the White House
during the protests of the night before

Trump then walked to [[St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square|St. John's Episcopal Church]], which during the night before had experienced a small fire contained to one room of the church, according to the church's rector. Trump posed for photographs in front of the church, holding a Bible aloft, and then had Cabinet members join him for more photos before walking back to the White House.

Trump did not enter the church during this appearance. Religious leaders across the United States condemned the treatment of protesters; the photo op itself was also criticized by leaders of different faiths. Meanwhile, many retired military leaders and retired defense officials condemned Trump's proposal to use the U.S. military against the protesters.
As of May 2020, North Korea has shown no indication that it is willing to unilaterally denuclearize as Trump has urged it to.
/* North Korea */

A summit was arranged; Trump cancelled it, then later reinstated it. On June 12, 2018, Trump and Kim met in Singapore, resulting in North Korea affirming its intention "to work toward complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula
both countries blamed each other
[[second Trump–Kim summit]]
trim
[[Kim Jong-un]]

Also in September 2017, Trump increased sanctions on North Korea, declared that he wanted North Korea's "complete denuclearization", and engaged in [[name-calling]] with North Korean leader [[Kim Jong-Un]].
In August 2017, Trump escalated his rhetoric against North Korea, warning that North Korean threats would be met with "fire and fury like the world has never seen".
In 2017, improved technology resulted in North Korea's nuclear weapons becoming increasingly seen as a serious threat to the United States.

North Korea responded by releasing plans for missile tests that would land near [[Guam]], a U.S. territory. In September, Trump addressed the [[United Nations General Assembly]], stating that the U.S. would "totally destroy North Korea" if "forced" to defend itself or its allies.

Since the government funding was temporary, another shutdown loomed. Trump signed the bill on February 15, 2019, just hours before another shutdown would begin.
temporary funding bill

On January 25, 2019, the Senate and the House unanimously approved a funding bill for the government, that provided no funding for the Trump wall, but would provide delayed paychecks to the government workers. Trump signed the bill that day, ending the shutdown at 35 days. It was the [[List of United States federal funding gaps|longest U.S. government shutdown in history]].
most of the affected workers missed two paychecks. The shutdown resulted in a permanent loss of $3 billion to the U.S. economy, estimated the Congressional Budget Office.[6]

Undid revision 958656741 by [[Special:Contributions/Nightscream|Nightscream]] ([[User talk:Nightscream|talk]]) - Disagree. Grammatically, the word "Early" has to modify either the first element only (life) or all three (life, career, military deferment). NOT the first two only. "Early military deferment" obviously makes no sense. Grammatical correctness trumps arguably unnecessary accuracy.

Redundant. "Early life" encompasses all those things that occur during that period, INCLUDING one's education. If anything, stuff in this section that is not typically found in the EL sections of bio articles would be his first work, and his military deferment.
